segment.source: Port from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11
segment.target: Port from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11

segment.source: Includes articles, overviews, and walkthroughs for porting an OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline to a Direct3D 11 and the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Includes articles, overviews, and walkthroughs for porting an OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline to a Direct3D 11 and the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Port from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11
segment.target: Port from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: Includes articles, overviews, and walkthroughs for porting an OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline to a Direct3D 11 and the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Includes articles, overviews, and walkthroughs for porting an OpenGL ES 2.0 graphics pipeline to a Direct3D 11 and the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Note An intermediate step to porting your OpenGL ES 2.0 project is to use ANGLE for Windows Store.
segment.target: Note An intermediate step to porting your OpenGL ES 2.0 project is to use ANGLE for Windows Store.

segment.source: ANGLE allows you to run OpenGL ES content on Windows by translating OpenGL ES API calls to DirectX 11 API calls.
segment.target: ANGLE allows you to run OpenGL ES content on Windows by translating OpenGL ES API calls to DirectX 11 API calls.

segment.source: For more information about ANGLE, go to the ANGLE for Windows Store Wiki.
segment.target: For more information about ANGLE, go to the ANGLE for Windows Store Wiki.

segment.source: Topic
segment.target: Topic

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Map OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.1
segment.target: Map OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.1

segment.source: When starting the process of porting your graphics architecture from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D for the first time, familiarize yourself with the key differences between the APIs.
segment.target: When starting the process of porting your graphics architecture from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D for the first time, familiarize yourself with the key differences between the APIs.

segment.source: The topics in this section help you plan your port strategy and the API changes that you must make when moving your graphics processing to Direct3D.
segment.target: The topics in this section help you plan your port strategy and the API changes that you must make when moving your graphics processing to Direct3D.

segment.source: How to: port a simple OpenGL ES 2.0 renderer to Direct3D 11.1
segment.target: How to: port a simple OpenGL ES 2.0 renderer to Direct3D 11.1

segment.source: For this porting exercise, we'll start with the basics: bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: For this porting exercise, we'll start with the basics: bringing a simple renderer for a spinning, vertex-shaded cube from OpenGL ES 2.0 into Direct3D, such that it matches the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template from Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.1 reference
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.1 reference

segment.source: Use these reference topics to look up API mapping and short code samples when porting from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.
segment.target: Use these reference topics to look up API mapping and short code samples when porting from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
